posts.name: Emmett Sisson
posts.cooked: My team’s Reefscape robot used MAXSwerve along with Vortexes and NEO 550s this season. I’m wondering if there’s a measurable limitation preventing MAXSwerve from allowing non-550 turning motors or if there’s a point where adding more turning motors doesn’t improve performance much. Additionally, has anyone successfully modified their own modules to use a different turning motor than the 550? This season, we encountered so many issues with the 550s that the idea of discontinuing them entirely for future robots is something we’re considering. Thank you!

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: A bigger motor will likely fail less often, though there may be some performance costs involved which aren't huge.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Adam
posts.cooked: We just finished our third season with MAX Swerve. NEO 550s are tiny and awful, especially when it comes to those fragile encoder cables. We’re currently exploring options for turning, including considering a custom adapter for CTRE Minions or upgrading to Mark IV. I’ll be sure to update this thread if we develop a Minion adapter.

posts.name: Emmett Sisson
posts.cooked: Completely switching to a different swerve system is something I’d like to do, but the cost involved is quite high—even after our recent investment in MAXSwerve. I’m considering building an adapter to utilize a regular NEO, given that we have many NEOs lying around.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked:
What issues in particular are you having?

I’ve found 550s to be pretty reliable. Just be cautious with the encoder cable and perhaps apply a small amount of hot glue to the CAN bus connectors on the Spark Max.

To remove the encoder cable, I typically use a small flathead screwdriver to gently pry out each side of the connector incrementally until it comes loose.

In any case, once the 550 is installed, it operates reliably like any other motor.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
Here is the cleaned-up version of your text, formatted into a single coherent paragraph while preserving the original meaning and adhering to standard English grammar and punctuation:

Viggy96 mentions that 550s are quite reliable. With anything exceeding a 15A current limit, they are likely to fail before a full season. These motors are highly sensitive to impacts and vibrations. Bigger motors tend to be stronger, and scaling laws play a significant role in their performance.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked:
Sure! Here’s the cleaned-up version of your text:

"Hmm, at least in the application OP is referring to, where I’ve set a 20A limit—believed to be the current limit suggested in the MAXSwerve template—I’ve never encountered any issues. Additionally, several neighboring teams also utilize MAXSwerve without any problems.

The only minor drawback of MAXSwerve that I’ve noticed is that the motors are exposed since they are located on the top of the module. This exposure means that intake ports or other attachments from other robots could potentially collide with or damage them."

posts.name: Ben Edwards
posts.cooked: We've never burned one out, and we've removed the encoder wiring. Ideally, you'd want to replace the 550 with a unit featuring an integrated motor controller, such as the Kraken X44. However, packaging such a solution proves to be very challenging.

posts.name: James Lyon
posts.cooked: Replacing the motor on the MAX Swerve would likely be challenging. Every part below the ultraplantary system consists of custom hardware, and constructing your own might be necessary. I'm not entirely sure if the ultraplantary system can support a larger motor.

posts.name: Ben Edwards
posts.cooked:
Two possibilities, both difficult.  
1 - Adapt a NEO or SplineXS motor to use an Ultraplanetary input pinon. In theory, you could trim the shaft of a NEO or SplineXS motor to fit a press on pinion. A 3D printed adapter could then adjust the bolt circle to match the Ultraplanetary. This might work, though it feels a bit odd. You could potentially reduce the stage ratio to 5:1 on the UP and expect it to handle torque effectively.  

2 - Build your own custom gearbox that integrates with a NEO or SplineXS motor, connecting directly to the big steering gear to replace the Ultraplanetary entirely.  

If you're looking for a compact swerve platform with a powerful steering motor, I recommend purchasing a SwerveX2S. While you CAN modify the Maxswerve to use a non-550 steering motor, this adaptation isn't easy, and unless you plan to showcase this ability, it might not be worth the effort.

posts.name: Emmett Sisson
posts.cooked:
The pinions on several components were slipping despite using a significant amount of loctite, causing frequent free-spinning and requiring us to dismantle the entire assembly. Additionally, the UltraPlanetary mounting mechanism tended to loosen quickly, which may have been avoidable given the circumstances.

From feedback received, it appears that transitioning the torque motor from a 550-volt system might exceed my current capabilities. I truly value all the insights shared by others.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: The friction-fit pinion, which you use an arbor press to install, appears to be a manufacturing issue. The 550-series pinion should remain securely attached without requiring threadlocker.

We’ve tested all of our 550s at a 20-amp limit for over three seasons, including those in our swerve modules, without any issues. Particularly when considering the turning motor, there’s little to no concern about it getting smoked because we’ve never experienced a situation where the motors were stalled under normal operation. Even if one wheel gets stuck, with a 20-amp limit, it would take a long time before a 550 volt system starts to smoke.

It’s fairly easy to replace the encoder wires if you do break them off—you just need a JST connector set and crimper, though technically the soldering iron isn’t necessary, but it can make things much easier. We even swapped one out during a match at our first competition after a falling coral landed directly on one of our encoder wires.

posts.name: Xavier E.
posts.cooked:
We’ve been using the MAXSwerve for three seasons now, and our only issue has been the sensor wires from the motors and the encoder wire. We switched to NEO Vortexes and SparkFlexes this year and thoroughly enjoyed it. I was really hoping REV would upgrade the 550s to not require the SparkMaxes, but maybe in the future they will.  

I don’t think the 550s limit anything on the MAXSwerve, but I’d love the ability to use another motor instead if possible.

Retaining compound may work better than regular threadlocker for a shaft slippage issue. That said, slipped shafts on a 550 pinion do sound like a QA issue, something worth contacting REV about if it becomes more frequent in the future.

posts.name: Ben Edwards
posts.cooked: We pulled one set of motor sense wires completely out of the motor. Nothing left to solder or crimp to, so we had to toss that one unfortunately. Other sets of sense wires have broken and been repaired, mainly because other robots got into places we didn’t think possible.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: For what it’s worth, I’ve seen this failure with press-fit pulleys on Neo550s before. Retaining compound can help, but the shaft is pretty tiny. This is part of the larger motors being more robust equation.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked: If I recall correctly, early neo550s had a quality issue with shaft diameter or finish? The recommended fix is locktite/retaining compound.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: Well, regardless of anything, if there's a quality issue, OP should contact REV and get replacement motors. They tend to handle replacements for defects pretty well.
